Text1Text: Constantly overshoots target, wide swings, slow to correct
column8: Some overshooting or missing of target, but quick to correct
column10: Accurately directs instruments in the correct plane to target

Text1Text: Uses only one hand, ignores nondominant hand, poor coordination between hands
column8: Uses both hands, but does not optimize interaction between hands
column10: Expertly uses both hands in a complementary way to provide optimal exposure

column8: constantly changing focus or pesisting without progress
column10: Slow, but planned movements are reasonably organized
column12: Confident, efficient and safe conduct, maintains focus on task until it is better performed by way of an alternative approach

Text1Text: Rough movements, tears tissue, injures adjacent structures, poor grasper control, grasper frequently slips
column8: Handles tissues reasonably well, minor trauma to adjacent tissue (ie, occasional unnecessary bleeding or slipping of the grasper)
column10: Handles tissues well, applies appropriate traction, negligible injury to adjacent structures

Text1Text: Unable to complete entire task, even with verbal guidance
column8: Able to complete task safely with moderate guidance
column10: Able to complete task independently without prompting

Object4rating: Uses cautery only when all conducting areas are in field of view
Has good control of the instrument, minimizes recoil
Grasps gallbladder near clips to begin dissection
Readjusts tension on gallbladder to optimize exposure
Avoids dissecting into liver causing undue bleeding
Maximizes usefull dissection in 1 area before changing approach
Performs dissection in appropriate plane the majority of the time
Obviates the need for surgeon takeover
